awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Implantable Medical Device and Body Area Networks: A System Resilience by Construction
awd_abstract_narration:
The advances of low-power and highly integrated technology provide enormous opportunities for the deployment of implantable medical devices (IMDs) and body area networks (BANs). BANs and IMDs either provide critical clinical information for medical decision-making or directly deliver medical treatment to maintain an individual?s health status. However, failures of these devices, either caused by device faults or malicious attacks, can have negative impact on the user?s health or even cause the loss of life. The significant increase in device complexity has created major challenges in ensuring reliability, safety, and security of these devices. First, researchers from the different domains, specifically engineering and medicine, have developed their respective perspectives, concerns and definitions regarding patient safety, security, and dependability.  In fact, the concept of (patient) safety is often compromised by inconsistent use of language.  The lack of a consistent understanding of the perspectives with respect to the healthcare and engineering disciplines could be the cause of the rising number of recalls and adverse events of medical devices in recent years, as recorded by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA).  In addition, the consideration of safety and security in the design of these devices is often ignored or overlooked in the design phase due to the limited time-to-market and lack of knowledge of the area of fault tolerant and dependable system design.  

This work proposes to consider a new system-resilience design methodology which integrates the multidiscipline perspectives and considers the many dimensions of complexity and design constraints to design a system that continuously prevents, detects, mitigates, or ameliorates hazards and incidents. The intellectual merit of this project is in development of a generalized fault-tolerant model-based technique that applies the principle of "resilience-by-construction" to design of the next generation IMDs and BANs. The main goal is to develop a design methodology that provides the automatic inclusion of safety monitors in any functional design without the designer having to explicitly designate monitors during the design process. To be specific, this design methodology/framework includes: (i) a rigorous safety requirement development environment that enables the close and effective collaboration between engineers, medical professionals, and regulators to identify all the potential safety hazards and develop safety requirements that guide product design; and (ii) a  standardized architecture for more resilient BANs and IMDs that enables the designers to concentrate on the development of a functional device and not be concerned about the safety and fault tolerance features. Once the functional architecture is complete, the designer will be able to add standardized hardware and software safety mechanisms based on the specific safety requirements of the device. Both model-based and knowledge-based fault detection and diagnosis methods and the combination of the two will be investigated for design of effective standardized safety mechanisms.

por.por_cntn:
Rapid advances in low-power sensing and integrated circuit technologies have led to the proliferation of wearable and implantable medical devices in various diagnostic and therapeutic applications. However, with increasing device complexity and connectivity, shrinking technology sizes, and shorter time to market, ensuring reliability, safety, and security of medical devices is very challenging. Recent studies have shown the susceptibility of medical devices (e.g., patient monitors, infusion pumps, and implantable pacemakers) to accidental faults or malicious attacks with potential adverse impacts on patients. Despite significant efforts on risk assessment, formal analysis, model-based design, and automated synthesis methods, residual faults and attacks can evade rigorous design and verification methods and appear at runtime. However, the inclusion of runtime safety monitoring and fault-tolerance mechanisms is often overlooked in the design of these small devices due to tight resource constraints and limited time to market. 

This project focused on developing a resilience-by-construction methodology based on automated design and synthesis of runtime context-aware safety monitors that can be integrated with the input/output interface of a target medical device controller (e.g., an artificial pancreas controller) at design time to continuously assess the safety of control actions delivered from the controller to the physical process (e.g., infusion pump and patient) at runtime. The proposed monitoring system uses the input and output from the controller to identify the control actions issued by the controller and the physical context under which they are going to be enacted to detect and mitigate unsafe control actions that most likely lead to safety hazards and harm to patients. 

We developed a framework for systems-theoretic modeling of the controller functionality and the formal specification of its safety requirements and their patient-specific refinement using data traces collected from the patient-in-the-loop system. The proposed framework closes the gap between the design-time hazard analysis and the runtime safety monitoring approaches. It enables the safety engineers and clinicians to collaborate on the specification safety requirements based on domain knowledge and the optimization of safety properties using patient data. We evaluated the performance of the proposed context-aware monitoring approach for the case study of artificial pancreas systems for diabetes management. We also demonstrated the potential to generalize the proposed approach to other safety-critical systems by applying it to a case study of autonomous driving systems. The simulation environment for the experimental evaluation of different runtime monitors is publicly available as an online repository. This research resulted in four publications and a MSc. thesis, and supported two graduate students and mentoring of three undergraduate researchers. Two of these students continued to pursue a Ph.D. degree.

The new resilience-by-construction design methodology can enable the development of the next generation of safe and secure medical devices that can predict, prevent, and mitigate catastrophic events. The real-time safety monitoring techniques developed as part of this project can detect the early signs of adverse events during the use of medical devices and mitigate them before causing harm to patients, thus, eventually leading to reducing the number of adverse events reported for medical devices. The proposed approach to runtime safety monitoring is also applicable to predicting safety violations and preventing accidents in other safety-critical cyber-physical systems.
